Isn't this the same as saying that you don't have to test
units/ classes since if the user interface has been proven to behave
correctly, 
then the units/ classes has been proven to be bug free.
I think this is a spooky approach.
By the way, has anybody an idea of how to test private methods in servlets?

Trond Lindanger


-----Original Message-----
From: rainsber@... [mailto:rainsber@...]
Sent: 28. juni 2001 17:52
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Testing Private Methods


Yes. Don't test protected and package-protected methods.

A quote from the XP discussion group.
(http://208.48.218.9/group/extremeprogramming/message/13213)

"I actually do think that it is cut and dried. Public members have a
behavior that is expected of them by their clients. Tests can be used to
define that behavior and demonstrate that a particular method exhibits it.
Private methods are, by definition, implementation details. Their behavior
can vary freely so long as the public methods don't break. Put another way:
if every public method has been proven to behave correctly then the class
has been proven to be bug free. Therefore, there is never a need to test
the private members of a class."

So can you avoid testing them? If so, then don't; if not, then you can't
have it both ways: either the tests are in the class (to test private
methods),
in the package (to test protected/package methods) or you can't test those
methods. There's no magic here...

Good luck,

J. B. Rainsberger  <rainsber@...>

"Mike Witters" <mikew@...> on 06/28/2001 09:06:18

Please respond to junit@yahoogroups.com

To:   <junit@yahoogroups.com>
cc:
Subject:  [junit] Testing Private Methods



Hello.

Can anyone point me to a good source of information on using JUNIT for
testing private methods and package-protected methods.  It seems like its
not going to be possible to do it while separating the TestCase classes and
the business object classes.

One of the reasons I see a difficulty is that we are using VisualAge for
Java and it would make it a deployment nightmare to include the code in the
same packages or, worse yet, the same classes.  I know that there are
options I could use outside of VA such as ANT to only build certain
classes,
but I doubt I could get the client to buy into that and I still don't think
that solves the private method issue.

Am I just missing something easy or what?

Thanks,
Mike
